texts.shortText: Very easily identified to group, as the body is long, soft, and cylindrical and the segments greatly elongated, each bearing short rows of hooked setae. The body thus resembles a length of bamboo. Each species has a consistent number of segments. The head in this genus is unusual, comprising a flat, oblique plate with a raised rim and no other appendages. The even more characteristic last segment is in the form of a frilly, flared funnel, within which the anus opens. There are about 10 regional species and these are difficult to distinguish from one another.

Global: The group is widespread, but as this entry is not to species level, global distribution cannot be given.

Local/Regional: Members of genus found across region.

Burrow head down into the sediments and secrete a friable tube made out of pieces of shell and sand cemented together with a membranous lining. The anal cone blocks the upper entrance to the tube. Found on sheltered sandbanks and also in sandy pools on rocky shores.
Ingest sand, from which they digest organic particles, including protists and bacteria.

Little is known about reproduction in this group, but sexes are separate and it is assumed that sperm and eggs are released into the water column and that these develop into planktonic larvae. Have good powers of regeneration and if segments are lost the exact correct number of segments typical of each species is regenerated.

Easy to identify to group, but there are several species that can only be distinguished by microscopic examination. The genus Nicomache is similar in overall body form, but the head has an arched dorsal keel and lacks the flat plate found in Euclymene. Again there are several species which make sandy tubes, typically on boulders partially buried in sand.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 64).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 645 onwards).
